content.description: <math alttext="H N O 2 aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus N O 2 with a negative 1 charge aqueous. p K sub a equals 3.25" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Sample Solution Composition <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="bold"><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 1 <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution 3.26 2 <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution 3.25 3 <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution and one drop of <math alttext="H C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 3.03 4 <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution 3.21 5 <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution 3.25 The acid ionization equilibrium for <math alttext="H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the equation above. A <math alttext="250.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer solution is prepared by mixing <math alttext="125.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>125.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.20 molar H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="125.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>125.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.1 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.10</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mi>M</mi> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>NaOH</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. To test the buffer capacity, the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured and recorded in the table for four samples of the buffer and one sample of a mixture of the buffer and <math alttext="H C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following best helps explain why the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of sample 4 is lower than the pH of the other samples containing only buffer solution?

choices.label: Prior to measuring the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of sample 4, some water evaporated, resulting in an increase in the concentration of <math alttext="H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample.

After measuring the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the more acidic sample 3, the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> probe was not rinsed and wiped, resulting in the neutralization of a very small amount of the conjugate base in sample 4.

Prior to measuring the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of sample 4, the room temperature dropped suddenly, resulting in an increase in the <math alttext="p K sub a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The volume used to measure the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of sample 4 was less than <math alttext="25.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of <math alttext="N O 2 with a negative 1 charge " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: After measuring the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the more acidic sample 3, the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> probe was not rinsed and wiped, resulting in the neutralization of a very small amount of the conjugate base in sample 4.

skill.text: 6.G: Explain how potential sources of experimental error may affect the experimental results.
